prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 continuum: Borasisi
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This project aims to measure Borosisi's continuum at band 7 to constrain its albedo and diameter, hence density.
The target is a moving object. Therefore, the most recent ephemeris at the time of the observation should be used for the field setup (coordinates, proper motion).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Time constraints: TNOs are moving objects. The target needs to be observed when high in the sky (elevation >30 deg). The most recent ephemeris at the time of the observation should be used for the field setup (coordinates, proper motion).
Borasisi is a very faint object: expected thermal flux at 350 Ghz ranges from 0.023 to 0.122 mJy. With a 2-hour observation time, we will reach a sensitivity of 0.019 mJy, which will allow a ~1 to 6 snr detection. If the detection is very poor, this will confirm that Borasisi is indeed a very small object with a very strong albedo, and therefore an outlier of the global size/density picture. If, on the contrary, the current observed bimodality between small and large TNOs is true, Borasisi will have a smaller density thus a larger diameter, and will be detected with SNR>3.
The expected fluxes in band 7 (and accompanying rms) were calculated using a model developed by Groussin et al. [Groussin et al. 2011] and exposure times using the ALMA Integration Time Calculator.
Correlator setup: Our objective is to detect the continuum emission. Therefore, we only require the low-resolution/TDM correlator setup, with a spectral resolution of 31.25 MHz and the largest bandwidth available: 2 GHz in the 4 basebands in dual polarization, and any spatial resolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 continuum: 2003 MW12
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This project aims to measure 2003 MW12 continuum at band 7 to constrain its albedo and diameter, hence density.
The target is a moving object. Therefore, the most recent ephemeris at the time of the observation should be used for the field setup (coordinates, proper motion).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Time constraints: TNOs are moving objects. Each target needs to be observed when high in the sky (elevation >30 deg). The most recent ephemeris at the time of the observation should be used for the field setup (coordinates, proper motion).
In order to constrain the albedo and the equivalent diameter of our binary targets, we need to observe their thermal flux in one band (350 GHz). To constrain the diameter with a 10% error (and the albedo with a 20% error) will require an rms of 20% in band 7 while an rms of 5% will lead to a constraint of the diameter with a 2-3% error (and the albedo with a 5% error).
For intermediate-sized objects like 2003 MW12, we request a signal-to-noise of 10 to 20 (rms of 10% to 5%) in order to constrain their equivalent diameter with a ~2-5% uncertainty. As of today, the diameter of 2003 MW12 is known with an uncertainty of ~11% and therefore an error on the volume of ~30%. With our new measurements, the error on the diameter will be reduced to ~2-3% and therefore the error on the volume to 6-9%. In conclusion, our new measurement will allow to reduce the error on the volume (hence the density) by a factor of ~5.
The expected fluxes in band 7 (and accompanying rms) were calculated using a model developed by Groussin et al. [Groussin et al. 2011] and exposure times using the ALMA Integration Time Calculator.
Correlator setup: Our objective is to detect the continuum emission. Therefore, we only require the low-resolution/TDM correlator setup, with a spectral resolution of 31.25 MHz and the largest bandwidth available: 2 GHz in the 4 basebands in dual polarization, and any spatial resolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 continuum: 2007 UK126
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This project aims to measure 2007 UK126's continuum at band 7 to constrain its albedo and diameter, hence density.
The target is a moving object. Therefore, the most recent ephemeris at the time of the observation should be used for the field setup (coordinates, proper motion).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Time constraints: TNOs are moving objects. Each target needs to be observed when high in the sky (elevation >30 deg). The most recent ephemeris at the time of the observation should be used for the field setup (coordinates, proper motion).
In order to constrain the albedo and the equivalent diameter of our binary targets, we need to observe their thermal flux in one band (350 GHz). To constrain the diameter with a 10% error (and the albedo with a 20% error) will require an rms of 20% in band 7 while an rms of 5% will lead to a constraint of the diameter with a 2-3% error (and the albedo with a 5% error).
For intermediate-sized objects like 2007 UK126, we request a signal-to-noise of 10 to 20 (rms of 10% to 5%) in order to constrain their equivalent diameter with a ~2-5% uncertainty. As of today, the diameter of 2007 UK126 is known with an uncertainty of ~13% and therefore an error on the volume of ~40%. With our new measurements, the error on the diameter will be reduced to ~2-3% and therefore the error on the volume to ~6-9%. In conclusion, our new measurement will allow to reduce the error on the volume (hence the density) by a factor of ~5.
The expected fluxes in band 7 (and accompanying rms) were calculated using a model developed by Groussin et al. [Groussin et al. 2011] and exposure times using the ALMA Integration Time Calculator.
Correlator setup: Our objective is to detect the continuum emission. Therefore, we only require the low-resolution/TDM correlator setup, with a spectral resolution of 31.25 MHz and the largest bandwidth available: 2 GHz in the 4 basebands in dual polarization, and any spatial resolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 continuum: 2000 YW134
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This project aims to measure 2000 YW134's continuum at band 7 to constrain its albedo and diameter, hence density.
The target is a moving object. Therefore, the most recent ephemeris at the time of the observation should be used for the field setup (coordinates, proper motion).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Time constraints: TNOs are moving objects. Each target needs to be observed when high in the sky (elevation >30 deg). The most recent ephemeris at the time of the observation should be used for the field setup (coordinates, proper motion).
In order to constrain the albedo and the equivalent diameter of our binary targets, we need to observe their thermal flux in one band (350 GHz). To constrain the diameter with a 10% error (and the albedo with a 20% error) will require a rms of 20% in band 7 while a rms of 5% will lead to a constraint of the diameter with a 2-3% error (and the albedo with a 5% error).
Concerning 2000 YW134, only an upper limit on the diameter (500 km) and a lower limit on the albedo (0.08) are currently known. With our measurements, we will obtain a first properly estimated albedo with an error of ~10%, and a diameter with an error of ~5%, thus an error on the volume (and density) of ~15%.
The expected fluxes in band 7 (and accompanying rms) were calculated using a model developed by Groussin et al. [Groussin et al. 2011] and exposure times using the ALMA Integration Time Calculator.
Correlator setup: Our objective is to detect the continuum emission. Therefore, we only require the low-resolution/TDM correlator setup, with a spectral resolution of 31.25 MHz and the largest bandwidth available: 2 GHz in the 4 basebands in dual polarization, and any spatial resolution.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The difference in density between small (D<400km) and large (D>1000km) Trans-Neptunian Objects (TNOs) either implies significant porosity in the smallest objects (case A) or a different composition (ice/rock ratio) and hence a different location and/or epoch of formation for small and large TNOs (case B). If porosity does occur on the smallest objects, measured densities should begin to increase at the size at which significant porosity is no longer supported. Here, we propose to observe mainly intermediate sized binary TNOs (400<D<1000km) as well as a small TNO (Borasisi) whose high density does not fit in the global picture, to bring significant progress on this question. Specifically, we will perform continuum flux observations in band 7 of 4 binary systems, which will allow us to determine their equivalent diameter, hence their density.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Prog. ID: 2012.1.00143.S Physical properties of the nucleus of comet C/2011 L4 (Pan-STARRS) PI: Groussin, O.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Unidad de Astronomía, Facultad de Ciencias Básicas, Universidad de Antofagasta
